awd_titl_txt: Probing support-solvent-solute interactions in heterogeneous catalysts by surface-sensitive magnetic resonance tools
awd_abstract_narration:
The manufacturing of chemicals from renewable biomass is an important, long term alternative to petroleum. Co-production of higher-value chemicals can also help to make these processes more economical. However, biomass has a high oxygen content. To make useful chemicals, this oxygen must first be removed. Dehydration is one important route to reducing oxygen content. With this funding from the NSF Division of Chemistry, Drs. Han and Scott of the University of California Santa Barbara are investigating these dehydration reactions. The role of solvents and catalysts are being studied to aid in the design of more effective catalysts for these reactions. At the same time, powerful new measurement methods for probing the fundamental chemistry are being developed. The graduate students on the project are acquiring advanced research skills, and learning to integrate their findings with collaborators. They are also gaining international and industrial perspectives of their research. The PIs and their students are mentoring younger, at-risk students, who are also experiencing first-hand experimental problem-solving.

The efficient conversion of biomass-derived polyols to value-added renewable chemicals by dehydration is an important challenge for heterogeneous catalysis. Conducting such reactions selectively in semi-aqueous solvent systems, under mild reaction conditions, requires the development of highly active, hydrothermally stable catalysts. Their activity can be enhanced by tuning the solvent composition and the catalyst support to promote the partitioning of dissolved reactant molecules to the catalytically active solid, and adsorbed product molecules back into solution. This project elucidates and quantifies the interdependent solid-solvent-solute interactions that control activity and selectivity in catalytic dehydration reactions. In the presence of solid catalysts for acid-catalyzed alcohol dehydration reactions, the dynamics of adsorbed reactants and products, the surface-coupled solvent dynamics, and the partitioning of (co-)solutes to the surface relative to bulk, are being characterized with molecular precision. The measurements are made possible by state-of-the-art, surface-sensitive magnetic resonance tools, including solid-state magic-angle spinning (MAS) dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) NMR to characterize catalyst supports and active sites with dramatically enhanced sensitivity, and Overhauser DNP to measure the surface diffusivity of solvent molecules which is correlated with the solvation barrier to adsorption. The key questions being addressed are: (1) How can catalytic activity and selectivity in polyol dehydration be controlled, by varying the solvation barrier for solute adsorption to the catalyst surface? (2) How can the solvation barrier for solute approach be modulated, by tuning the hydrophobicity of the catalyst surface and the composition of the solvent mixture? The study generates a basis for new structure-property-function relationships in liquid-phase heterogeneous catalysis, exploring their validity in an important family of reactions for the upgrading of biomass-derived polyols, and advancing the development of surface-sensitive magnetic resonance-based tools to characterize heterogeneous catalysts. The graduate students involved with the project are learning advanced research techniques, and learning to integrate their findings with collaborators. They are also gaining international and industrial perspectives of their research. The PIs and their students are mentoring younger, at-risk students, who themselves are experiencing first-hand experimental problem-solving.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the collaborative work of the groups of Songi Han and Susannah Scott at the University of California Santa Barbara to experimentally probe support-solvent-solute interactions and test the hypothesis that structuring of near-surface water in organic-inorganic hybrid support surfaces is a critical mechanism to tune adsorption and catalysis. Many important chemical processes involve substrate binding at or near an active site on a surface, and subsequent catalytic transformation at the solid-liquid interface. Qualitatively, the role of solvation in modulating adsorption thermodynamics and/or influencing surface reaction rates is widely acknowledged. There is compelling new evidence for the influence of solvation entropy and confinement effects on reaction rates and selectivity in porous catalytic materials. However, quantitative evidence for solvation effects in heterogeneous catalysis is sparse, and direct experimental probes of solvation structure and thermodynamics are virtually non-existent.

The team focused on gaining fundamental insight into core concepts, such as elucidating the molecular signatures of surface hydrophobicity, clarifying the role of solvation in adsorption and chemical catalysis and developing experimental tools to directly examine the support surface-water interface—the latter is key because advanced experimental tools equip researchers to gain unbiased insight. The team designed a series of silica support surfaces with defined pore size distribution and properties, and with increasing hydrophobicity achieved in two different ways: by decreasing the hydrophilic surface silanol density and by increasing the surface density of organic linker moieties. A plethora of state of the art and novel magnetic resonance tools was employed to gain insight into the property of water at the interface, including Overhauser dynamic nuclear polarization to measure the near-surface water diffusivity, 17O NMR chemical shift analysis to identify near-surface water populations with distinct, 2D 17O-1H NMR to establish correlations between water and support surface moieties, operando NMR to track chemical transformation, and EPR lineshape analysis of grafted, paramagnetic, vanadium metal sites to surface silanol groups. Several surprising discoveries contradict prevailing hypotheses. Silanols remaining on amorphous silica surfaces upon thermal treatment above 700°C are concentrated in high-density patches of silanols with close (~5 Å) spacing, while 80-90 % of the support surface area consists of low density silanol patches. This is a different picture of thermally treated silica than generally assumed and changes the design strategies for grafting depending on whether clustered or site-isolated functional moieties are targeted. The near-surface water structure and dynamics responds in opposite ways to increasing hydrophobicity of amorphous silica, depending on whether surface silanol density is reduced or organic linker moieties are added. There is large length-scale behavior of increasing water dynamics with decreasing surface silanol density, which is due to decreasing enthalpy of interaction between water and the support surface. In contrast, water dynamics decrease with increasing hydrophobicity with greater incorporation of surface organic groups, consistent with near-surface water structuring around < 1 nm size organic groups. Clathrate-like ordering of water near small hydrophobic groups has been postulated by theorists for decades, but the direct experimental observation in commonly-used catalyst support materials means that these effects can be used in tuning the design of catalyst support surfaces. The team made progress towards the direct experimental detection of near-surface water structuring, as well as the eviction of this structured, low-entropy, water using methane—a method that is commonly used in computational chemistry but is a novel experimental tool. An additional implication of this finding is that methane uptake can be enhanced by tuning the surface hydrophobicity, but only using surfaces prepared to be wetted with near-surface structured water that is more easily evicted than water collectively wetting the hydrophilic silica as a film. The underlying core hypothesis pursued by the team is that hydration thermodynamics of structurally heterogeneous silica surfaces can be tuned to promote adsorption, which in turn tunes the selectivity in catalytic reaction. Operando NMR reaction monitoring of phenol hydrogenation was performed using Pd-supported on the same mesoporous silica characterized in detail. Clear differences in reactant adsorption, catalytic rates and product selectivity were observed, with the organosilica with near-surface water structuring showing superior performance over that of inorganic mesoporous silica. However, the mechanisms behind these effects are complex, and much more work needs to be done to fully understand the mechanism to the point where the material and experimental condition can be designed to achieve the desired turnover, reaction rate or selectivity. The work has laid a foundation by enhancing our understanding of the structure and property of water near silica support surfaces, establishing that there are critical connections between the support-solvent interactions and the performance of heterogeneous catalysis, and by developing surface-sensitive magnetic resonance tools to interrogate the support surface-reactant interface with a new vision.
